apidoc.top:
Defines an object that runs Selenium commands.
Element Locators
Element Locators tell Selenium which HTML element a command refers to. The format of a locator is:
locatorType=argument
We support the following strategies for locating elements:
identifier=id: Select the element with the specified @id attribute. If no match is found, select the first element whose @name attribute is id. (This is normally the default; see below.)
id=id: Select the element with the specified @id attribute.
name=name: Select the first element with the specified @name attribute.
username
name=username
The name may optionally be followed by one or more element-filters, separated from the name by whitespace. If the filterType is not specified, value is assumed.
name=flavour value=chocolate
dom=javascriptExpression:
Find an element by evaluating the specified string. This allows you to traverse the HTML Document Object Model using JavaScript. Note that you must not return a value in this string; simply make it the last expression in the block.
dom=document.forms['myForm'].myDropdown
dom=document.images[56]
dom=function foo() { return document.links[1]; }; foo();
xpath=xpathExpression: Locate an element using an XPath expression.
xpath=//img[@alt='The image alt text']
xpath=//table[@id='table1']//tr[4]/td[2]
xpath=//a[contains(@href,'#id1')]
xpath=//a[contains(@href,'#id1')]/@class
xpath=(//table[@class='stylee'])//th[text()='theHeaderText']/../td
xpath=//input[@name='name2' and @value='yes']
xpath=//*[text()="right"]
link=textPattern: Select the link (anchor) element which contains text matching the specified pattern.
link=The link text
css=cssSelectorSyntax: Select the element using css selectors. Please refer to CSS2 selectors, CSS3 selectors for more information. You can also check the TestCssLocators test in the selenium test suite for an example of usage, which is included in the downloaded selenium core package.
css=a[href="#id3"]
css=span#firstChild + span
Currently the css selector locator supports all css1, css2 and css3 selectors except namespace in css3, some pseudo classes(:nth-of-type, :nth-last-of-type, :first-of-type, :last-of-type, :only-of-type, :visited, :hover, :active, :focus, :indeterminate) and pseudo elements(::first-line, ::first-letter, ::selection, ::before, ::after).
Without an explicit locator prefix, Selenium uses the following default strategies:
dom, for locators starting with "document."
xpath, for locators starting with "//"
identifier, otherwise
Element Filters
Element filters can be used with a locator to refine a list of candidate elements. They are currently used only in the 'name' element-locator.
Filters look much like locators, ie.
filterType=argument
Supported element-filters are:
value=valuePattern
Matches elements based on their values. This is particularly useful for refining a list of similarly-named toggle-buttons.
index=index
Selects a single element based on its position in the list (offset from zero).
String-match Patterns
Various Pattern syntaxes are available for matching string values:
glob:pattern: Match a string against a "glob" (aka "wildmat") pattern. "Glob" is a kind of limited regular-expression syntax typically used in command-line shells. In a glob pattern, "*" represents any sequence of characters, and "?" represents any single character. Glob patterns match against the entire string.
regexp:regexp: Match a string using a regular-expression. The full power of JavaScript regular-expressions is available.
exact:string:
Match a string exactly, verbatim, without any of that fancy wildcard stuff.
If no pattern prefix is specified, Selenium assumes that it's a "glob" pattern.

function.name: click
function.param: an element locator
function.comment: Clicks on a link, button, checkbox or radio button. If the click action causes a new page to load (like a link usually does), call waitForPageToLoad.

function.name: doubleClick
function.param: an element locator
function.comment: Double clicks on a link, button, checkbox or radio button. If the double click action causes a new page to load (like a link usually does), call waitForPageToLoad.

function.name: clickAt
function.param: an element locator
specifies the x,y position (i.e. - 10,20) of the mouse event relative to the element returned by the locator.
function.comment: Clicks on a link, button, checkbox or radio button. If the click action causes a new page to load (like a link usually does), call waitForPageToLoad.

function.name: doubleClickAt
function.param: an element locator
specifies the x,y position (i.e. - 10,20) of the mouse event relative to the element returned by the locator.
function.comment: Doubleclicks on a link, button, checkbox or radio button. If the action causes a new page to load (like a link usually does), call waitForPageToLoad.

function.name: fireEvent
function.param: an element locator
the event name, e.g. "focus" or "blur"
function.comment: Explicitly simulate an event, to trigger the corresponding "onevent" handler.

function.name: keyPress
function.param: an element locator
Either be a string("\" followed by the numeric keycode of the key to be pressed, normally the ASCII value of that key), or a single character. For example: "w", "\119".
function.comment: Simulates a user pressing and releasing a key.

function.name: shiftKeyDown
function.comment: Press the shift key and hold it down until doShiftUp() is called or a new page is loaded.

function.name: shiftKeyUp
function.comment: Release the shift key.

function.name: metaKeyDown
function.comment: Press the meta key and hold it down until doMetaUp() is called or a new page is loaded.

function.name: metaKeyUp
function.comment: Release the meta key.

function.name: altKeyDown
function.comment: Press the alt key and hold it down until doAltUp() is called or a new page is loaded.

function.name: altKeyUp
function.comment: Release the alt key.

function.name: controlKeyDown
function.comment: Press the control key and hold it down until doControlUp() is called or a new page is loaded.

function.name: controlKeyUp
function.comment: Release the control key.

function.name: keyDown
function.param: an element locator
Either be a string("\" followed by the numeric keycode of the key to be pressed, normally the ASCII value of that key), or a single character. For example: "w", "\119".
function.comment: Simulates a user pressing a key (without releasing it yet).

function.name: keyUp
function.param: an element locator
Either be a string("\" followed by the numeric keycode of the key to be pressed, normally the ASCII value of that key), or a single character. For example: "w", "\119".
function.comment: Simulates a user releasing a key.

function.name: mouseOver
function.param: an element locator
function.comment: Simulates a user hovering a mouse over the specified element.

function.name: mouseOut
function.param: an element locator
function.comment: Simulates a user moving the mouse pointer away from the specified element.

function.name: mouseDown
function.param: an element locator
function.comment: Simulates a user pressing the mouse button (without releasing it yet) on the specified element.

function.name: mouseDownAt
function.param: an element locator
specifies the x,y position (i.e. - 10,20) of the mouse event relative to the element returned by the locator.
function.comment: Simulates a user pressing the mouse button (without releasing it yet) on the specified element.

function.name: mouseUp
function.param: an element locator
function.comment: Simulates a user pressing the mouse button (without releasing it yet) on the specified element.

function.name: mouseUpAt
function.param: an element locator
specifies the x,y position (i.e. - 10,20) of the mouse event relative to the element returned by the locator.
function.comment: Simulates a user pressing the mouse button (without releasing it yet) on the specified element.

function.name: mouseMove
function.param: an element locator
function.comment: Simulates a user pressing the mouse button (without releasing it yet) on the specified element.

function.name: mouseMoveAt
function.param: an element locator
specifies the x,y position (i.e. - 10,20) of the mouse event relative to the element returned by the locator.
function.comment: Simulates a user pressing the mouse button (without releasing it yet) on the specified element.

function.name: type
function.param: an element locator
the value to type
function.comment:
Sets the value of an input field, as though you typed it in.
Can also be used to set the value of combo boxes, check boxes, etc. In these cases, value should be the value of the option selected, not the visible text.

function.name: typeKeys
function.param: an element locator
the value to type
function.comment:
Simulates keystroke events on the specified element, as though you typed the value key-by-key.
This is a convenience method for calling keyDown, keyUp, keyPress for every character in the specified string; this is useful for dynamic UI widgets (like auto-completing combo boxes) that require explicit key events.
Unlike the simple "type" command, which forces the specified value into the page directly, this command may or may not have any visible effect, even in cases where typing keys would normally have a visible effect. For example, if you use "typeKeys" on a form element, you may or may not see the results of what you typed in the field.
In some cases, you may need to use the simple "type" command to set the value of the field and then the "typeKeys" command to send the keystroke events corresponding to what you just typed.

function.name: setSpeed
function.param: the number of milliseconds to pause after operation
function.comment: Set execution speed (i.e., set the millisecond length of a delay which will follow each selenium operation). By default, there is no such delay, i.e., the delay is 0 milliseconds.

function.name: getSpeed
function.comment:
Get execution speed (i.e., get the millisecond length of the delay following each selenium operation). By default, there is no such delay, i.e., the delay is 0 milliseconds.
See also setSpeed.

function.name: check
function.param: an element locator
function.comment: Check a toggle-button (checkbox/radio)

function.name: uncheck
function.param: an element locator
function.comment: Uncheck a toggle-button (checkbox/radio)

function.name: select
function.param: an element locator identifying a drop-down menu
an option locator (a label by default)
function.comment:
Select an option from a drop-down using an option locator.
Option locators provide different ways of specifying options of an HTML Select element (e.g. for selecting a specific option, or for asserting that the selected option satisfies a specification). There are several forms of Select Option Locator.
label=labelPattern: matches options based on their labels, i.e. the visible text. (This is the default.)
label=regexp:^[Oo]ther
value=valuePattern: matches options based on their values.
value=other
id=id:
matches options based on their ids.
id=option1
index=index: matches an option based on its index (offset from zero).
index=2
If no option locator prefix is provided, the default behaviour is to match on label.

function.name: addSelection
function.param: an element locator identifying a multi-select box
an option locator (a label by default)
function.comment:
Add a selection to the set of selected options in a multi-select element using an option locator.
@see #doSelect for details of option locators

function.name: removeSelection
function.param: an element locator identifying a multi-select box
an option locator (a label by default)
function.comment:
Remove a selection from the set of selected options in a multi-select element using an option locator.
@see #doSelect for details of option locators

function.name: removeAllSelections
function.param: an element locator identifying a multi-select box
function.comment: Unselects all of the selected options in a multi-select element.

function.name: submit
function.param: an element locator for the form you want to submit
function.comment: Submit the specified form. This is particularly useful for forms without submit buttons, e.g. single-input "Search" forms.

function.name: open
function.param: the URL to open; may be relative or absolute
function.comment:
Opens an URL in the test frame. This accepts both relative and absolute URLs.
The "open" command waits for the page to load before proceeding, ie. the "AndWait" suffix is implicit.
Note: The URL must be on the same domain as the runner HTML due to security restrictions in the browser (Same Origin Policy). If you need to open an URL on another domain, use the Selenium Server to start a new browser session on that domain.

function.name: openWindow
function.param: the URL to open, which can be blank
the JavaScript window ID of the window to select
function.comment:
Opens a popup window (if a window with that ID isn't already open). After opening the window, you'll need to select it using the selectWindow command.
This command can also be a useful workaround for bug SEL-339. In some cases, Selenium will be unable to intercept a call to window.open (if the call occurs during or before the "onLoad" event, for example). In those cases, you can force Selenium to notice the open window's name by using the Selenium openWindow command, using an empty (blank) url, like this: openWindow("", "myFunnyWindow").

function.name: selectWindow
function.param: the JavaScript window ID of the window to select
function.comment:
Selects a popup window; once a popup window has been selected, all commands go to that window. To select the main window again, use null as the target.
Selenium has several strategies for finding the window object referred to by the "windowID" parameter.
1.) if windowID is null, then it is assumed the user is referring to the original window instantiated by the browser).
2.) if the value of the "windowID" parameter is a JavaScript variable name in the current application window, then it is assumed that this variable contains the return value from a call to the JavaScript window.open() method.
3.) Otherwise, selenium looks in a hash it maintains that maps string names to window objects. Each of these string names matches the second parameter "windowName" past to the JavaScript method window.open(url, windowName, windowFeatures, replaceFlag) (which selenium intercepts).
If you're having trouble figuring out what is the name of a window that you want to manipulate, look at the selenium log messages which identify the names of windows created via window.open (and therefore intercepted by selenium). You will see messages like the following for each window as it is opened:
debug: window.open call intercepted; window ID (which you can use with selectWindow()) is "myNewWindow"
In some cases, Selenium will be unable to intercept a call to window.open (if the call occurs during or before the "onLoad" event, for example). (This is bug SEL-339.) In those cases, you can force Selenium to notice the open window's name by using the Selenium openWindow command, using an empty (blank) url, like this: openWindow("", "myFunnyWindow").

function.name: selectFrame
function.param: an element locator identifying a frame or iframe
function.comment:
Selects a frame within the current window. (You may invoke this command multiple times to select nested frames.) To select the parent frame, use "relative=parent" as a locator; to select the top frame, use "relative=top".
You may also use a DOM expression to identify the frame you want directly, like this: dom=frames["main"].frames["subframe"]

function.name: getLogMessages
function.return: all log messages seen since the last call to this API
function.comment:
Return the contents of the log.
This is a placeholder intended to make the code generator make this API available to clients. The selenium server will intercept this call, however, and return its recordkeeping of log messages since the last call to this API. Thus this code in JavaScript will never be called.
The reason I opted for a servercentric solution is to be able to support multiple frames served from different domains, which would break a centralized JavaScript logging mechanism under some conditions.

function.name: getWhetherThisFrameMatchFrameExpression
function.return: true if the new frame is this code's window
function.param: starting frame
new frame (which might be relative to the current one)
function.comment:
Determine whether current/locator identify the frame containing this running code.
This is useful in proxy injection mode, where this code runs in every browser frame and window, and sometimes the selenium server needs to identify the "current" frame. In this case, when the test calls selectFrame, this routine is called for each frame to figure out which one has been selected. The selected frame will return true, while all others will return false.

function.name: getWhetherThisWindowMatchWindowExpression
function.return: true if the new window is this code's window
function.param: starting window
new window (which might be relative to the current one, e.g., "_parent")
function.comment:
Determine whether currentWindowString plus target identify the window containing this running code.
This is useful in proxy injection mode, where this code runs in every browser frame and window, and sometimes the selenium server needs to identify the "current" window. In this case, when the test calls selectWindow, this routine is called for each window to figure out which one has been selected. The selected window will return true, while all others will return false.

function.name: waitForPopUp
function.param: the JavaScript window ID of the window that will appear
a timeout in milliseconds, after which the action will return with an error
function.comment: Waits for a popup window to appear and load up.

function.name: chooseCancelOnNextConfirmation
function.comment: By default, Selenium's overridden window.confirm() function will return true, as if the user had manually clicked OK. After running this command, the next call to confirm() will return false, as if the user had clicked Cancel.

function.name: answerOnNextPrompt
function.param: the answer to give in response to the prompt pop-up
function.comment: Instructs Selenium to return the specified answer string in response to the next JavaScript prompt [window.prompt()].

function.name: goBack
function.comment: Simulates the user clicking the "back" button on their browser.

function.name: refresh
function.comment: Simulates the user clicking the "Refresh" button on their browser.

function.name: close
function.comment: Simulates the user clicking the "close" button in the titlebar of a popup window or tab.

function.name: isAlertPresent
function.return: true if there is an alert
function.comment:
Has an alert occurred?
This function never throws an exception

function.name: isPromptPresent
function.return: true if there is a pending prompt
function.comment:
Has a prompt occurred?
This function never throws an exception

function.name: isConfirmationPresent
function.return: true if there is a pending confirmation
function.comment:
Has confirm() been called?
This function never throws an exception

function.name: getAlert
function.return: The message of the most recent JavaScript alert
function.comment:
Retrieves the message of a JavaScript alert generated during the previous action, or fail if there were no alerts.
Getting an alert has the same effect as manually clicking OK. If an alert is generated but you do not get/verify it, the next Selenium action will fail.
NOTE: under Selenium, JavaScript alerts will NOT pop up a visible alert dialog.
NOTE: Selenium does NOT support JavaScript alerts that are generated in a page's onload() event handler. In this case a visible dialog WILL be generated and Selenium will hang until someone manually clicks OK.

function.name: getConfirmation
function.return: the message of the most recent JavaScript confirmation dialog
function.comment:
Retrieves the message of a JavaScript confirmation dialog generated during the previous action.
By default, the confirm function will return true, having the same effect as manually clicking OK. This can be changed by prior execution of the chooseCancelOnNextConfirmation command. If an confirmation is generated but you do not get/verify it, the next Selenium action will fail.
NOTE: under Selenium, JavaScript confirmations will NOT pop up a visible dialog.
NOTE: Selenium does NOT support JavaScript confirmations that are generated in a page's onload() event handler. In this case a visible dialog WILL be generated and Selenium will hang until you manually click OK.

function.name: getPrompt
function.return: the message of the most recent JavaScript question prompt
function.comment:
Retrieves the message of a JavaScript question prompt dialog generated during the previous action.
Successful handling of the prompt requires prior execution of the answerOnNextPrompt command. If a prompt is generated but you do not get/verify it, the next Selenium action will fail.
NOTE: under Selenium, JavaScript prompts will NOT pop up a visible dialog.
NOTE: Selenium does NOT support JavaScript prompts that are generated in a page's onload() event handler. In this case a visible dialog WILL be generated and Selenium will hang until someone manually clicks OK.

function.name: getLocation
function.return: the absolute URL of the current page
function.comment: Gets the absolute URL of the current page.

function.name: getTitle
function.return: the title of the current page
function.comment: Gets the title of the current page.

function.name: getBodyText
function.return: the entire text of the page
function.comment: Gets the entire text of the page.

function.name: getValue
function.return: the element value, or "on/off" for checkbox/radio elements
function.param: an element locator
function.comment: Gets the (whitespace-trimmed) value of an input field (or anything else with a value parameter). For checkbox/radio elements, the value will be "on" or "off" depending on whether the element is checked or not.

function.name: getText
function.return: the text of the element
function.param: an element locator
function.comment: Gets the text of an element. This works for any element that contains text. This command uses either the textContent (Mozilla-like browsers) or the innerText (IE-like browsers) of the element, which is the rendered text shown to the user.

function.name: highlight
function.param: an element locator
function.comment: Briefly changes the backgroundColor of the specified element yellow. Useful for debugging.

function.name: getEval
function.return: the results of evaluating the snippet
function.param: the JavaScript snippet to run
function.comment:
Gets the result of evaluating the specified JavaScript snippet. The snippet may have multiple lines, but only the result of the last line will be returned.
Note that, by default, the snippet will run in the context of the "selenium" object itself, so this will refer to the Selenium object, and window will refer to the top-level runner test window, not the window of your application.
If you need a reference to the window of your application, you can refer to this.browserbot.getCurrentWindow() and if you need to use a locator to refer to a single element in your application page, you can use this.browserbot.findElement("foo") where "foo" is your locator.

function.name: isChecked
function.return: true if the checkbox is checked, false otherwise
function.param: an element locator pointing to a checkbox or radio button
function.comment: Gets whether a toggle-button (checkbox/radio) is checked. Fails if the specified element doesn't exist or isn't a toggle-button.

function.name: getTable
function.return: the text from the specified cell
function.param: a cell address, e.g. "foo.1.4"
function.comment: Gets the text from a cell of a table. The cellAddress syntax tableLocator.row.column, where row and column start at 0.

function.name: getSelectedLabels
function.return: an array of all selected option labels in the specified select drop-down
function.param: an element locator identifying a drop-down menu
function.comment: Gets all option labels (visible text) for selected options in the specified select or multi-select element.

function.name: getSelectedLabel
function.return: the selected option label in the specified select drop-down
function.param: an element locator identifying a drop-down menu
function.comment: Gets option label (visible text) for selected option in the specified select element.

function.name: getSelectedValues
function.return: an array of all selected option values in the specified select drop-down
function.param: an element locator identifying a drop-down menu
function.comment: Gets all option values (value attributes) for selected options in the specified select or multi-select element.

function.name: getSelectedValue
function.return: the selected option value in the specified select drop-down
function.param: an element locator identifying a drop-down menu
function.comment: Gets option value (value attribute) for selected option in the specified select element.

function.name: getSelectedIndexes
function.return: an array of all selected option indexes in the specified select drop-down
function.param: an element locator identifying a drop-down menu
function.comment: Gets all option indexes (option number, starting at 0) for selected options in the specified select or multi-select element.

function.name: getSelectedIndex
function.return: the selected option index in the specified select drop-down
function.param: an element locator identifying a drop-down menu
function.comment: Gets option index (option number, starting at 0) for selected option in the specified select element.

function.name: getSelectedIds
function.return: an array of all selected option IDs in the specified select drop-down
function.param: an element locator identifying a drop-down menu
function.comment: Gets all option element IDs for selected options in the specified select or multi-select element.

function.name: getSelectedId
function.return: the selected option ID in the specified select drop-down
function.param: an element locator identifying a drop-down menu
function.comment: Gets option element ID for selected option in the specified select element.

function.name: isSomethingSelected
function.return: true if some option has been selected, false otherwise
function.param: an element locator identifying a drop-down menu
function.comment: Determines whether some option in a drop-down menu is selected.

function.name: getSelectOptions
function.return: an array of all option labels in the specified select drop-down
function.param: an element locator identifying a drop-down menu
function.comment: Gets all option labels in the specified select drop-down.

function.name: getAttribute
function.return: the value of the specified attribute
function.param: an element locator followed by an
function.comment: Gets the value of an element attribute.

function.name: isTextPresent
function.return: true if the pattern matches the text, false otherwise
function.param: a pattern to match with the text of the page
function.comment: Verifies that the specified text pattern appears somewhere on the rendered page shown to the user.

function.name: isElementPresent
function.return: true if the element is present, false otherwise
function.param: an element locator
function.comment: Verifies that the specified element is somewhere on the page.

function.name: isVisible
function.return: true if the specified element is visible, false otherwise
function.param: an element locator
function.comment: Determines if the specified element is visible. An element can be rendered invisible by setting the CSS "visibility" property to "hidden", or the "display" property to "none", either for the element itself or one if its ancestors. This method will fail if the element is not present.

function.name: isEditable
function.return: true if the input element is editable, false otherwise
function.param: an element locator
function.comment: Determines whether the specified input element is editable, ie hasn't been disabled. This method will fail if the specified element isn't an input element.

function.name: getAllButtons
function.return: the IDs of all buttons on the page
function.comment:
Returns the IDs of all buttons on the page.
If a given button has no ID, it will appear as "" in this array.

function.name: getAllLinks
function.return: the IDs of all links on the page
function.comment:
Returns the IDs of all links on the page.
If a given link has no ID, it will appear as "" in this array.

function.name: getAllFields
function.return: the IDs of all field on the page
function.comment:
Returns the IDs of all input fields on the page.
If a given field has no ID, it will appear as "" in this array.

function.name: getAttributeFromAllWindows
function.return: the set of values of this attribute from all known windows.
function.param: name of an attribute on the windows
function.comment: Returns every instance of some attribute from all known windows.

function.name: dragdrop
function.param: an element locator
offset in pixels from the current location to which the element should be moved, e.g., "+70,-300"
function.comment: deprecated - use dragAndDrop instead

function.name: setMouseSpeed
function.param: the number of pixels between "mousemove" events
function.comment:
Configure the number of pixels between "mousemove" events during dragAndDrop commands (default=10).
Setting this value to 0 means that we'll send a "mousemove" event to every single pixel in between the start location and the end location; that can be very slow, and may cause some browsers to force the JavaScript to timeout.
If the mouse speed is greater than the distance between the two dragged objects, we'll just send one "mousemove" at the start location and then one final one at the end location.

function.name: getMouseSpeed
function.return: the number of pixels between "mousemove" events during dragAndDrop commands (default=10)
function.comment: Returns the number of pixels between "mousemove" events during dragAndDrop commands (default=10).

function.name: dragAndDrop
function.param: an element locator
offset in pixels from the current location to which the element should be moved, e.g., "+70,-300"
function.comment: Drags an element a certain distance and then drops it

function.name: dragAndDropToObject
function.param: an element to be dragged
an element whose location (i.e., whose center-most pixel) will be the point where locatorOfObjectToBeDragged is dropped
function.comment: Drags an element and drops it on another element

function.name: windowFocus
function.param: name of the window to be given focus
function.comment: Gives focus to a window

function.name: windowMaximize
function.param: name of the window to be enlarged
function.comment: Resize window to take up the entire screen

function.name: getAllWindowIds
function.return: the IDs of all windows that the browser knows about.
function.comment: Returns the IDs of all windows that the browser knows about.

function.name: getAllWindowNames
function.return: the names of all windows that the browser knows about.
function.comment: Returns the names of all windows that the browser knows about.

function.name: getAllWindowTitles
function.return: the titles of all windows that the browser knows about.
function.comment: Returns the titles of all windows that the browser knows about.

function.name: getHtmlSource
function.return: the entire HTML source
function.comment: Returns the entire HTML source between the opening and closing "html" tags.

function.name: setCursorPosition
function.param: an element locator pointing to an input element or textarea
the numerical position of the cursor in the field; position should be 0 to move the position to the beginning of the field. You can also set the cursor to -1 to move it to the end of the field.
function.comment: Moves the text cursor to the specified position in the given input element or textarea. This method will fail if the specified element isn't an input element or textarea.

function.name: getElementIndex
function.return: of relative index of the element to its parent (starting from 0)
function.param: an element locator pointing to an element
function.comment: Get the relative index of an element to its parent (starting from 0). The comment node and empty text node will be ignored.

function.name: isOrdered
function.return: true if two elements are ordered and have same parent, false otherwise
function.param: an element locator pointing to the first element
an element locator pointing to the second element
function.comment: Check if these two elements have same parent and are ordered. Two same elements will not be considered ordered.

function.name: getElementPositionLeft
function.return: of pixels from the edge of the frame.
function.param: an element locator pointing to an element OR an element itself
function.comment: Retrieves the horizontal position of an element

function.name: getElementPositionTop
function.return: of pixels from the edge of the frame.
function.param: an element locator pointing to an element OR an element itself
function.comment: Retrieves the vertical position of an element

function.name: getElementWidth
function.return: width of an element in pixels
function.param: an element locator pointing to an element
function.comment: Retrieves the width of an element

function.name: getElementHeight
function.return: height of an element in pixels
function.param: an element locator pointing to an element
function.comment: Retrieves the height of an element

function.name: getCursorPosition
function.return: the numerical position of the cursor in the field
function.param: an element locator pointing to an input element or textarea
function.comment:
Retrieves the text cursor position in the given input element or textarea; beware, this may not work perfectly on all browsers.
Specifically, if the cursor/selection has been cleared by JavaScript, this command will tend to return the position of the last location of the cursor, even though the cursor is now gone from the page. This is filed as SEL-243. This method will fail if the specified element isn't an input element or textarea, or there is no cursor in the element.

function.name: setContext
function.param: the message to be sent to the browser
one of "debug", "info", "warn", "error", sets the threshold for browser-side logging
function.comment:
Writes a message to the status bar and adds a note to the browser-side log.
If logLevelThreshold is specified, set the threshold for logging to that level (debug, info, warn, error).
(Note that the browser-side logs will not be sent back to the server, and are invisible to the Client Driver.)

function.name: getExpression
function.return: the value passed in
function.param: the value to return
function.comment:
Returns the specified expression.
This is useful because of JavaScript preprocessing. It is used to generate commands like assertExpression and waitForExpression.

function.name: waitForCondition
function.param: the JavaScript snippet to run
a timeout in milliseconds, after which this command will return with an error
function.comment:
Runs the specified JavaScript snippet repeatedly until it evaluates to "true". The snippet may have multiple lines, but only the result of the last line will be considered.
Note that, by default, the snippet will be run in the runner's test window, not in the window of your application. To get the window of your application, you can use the JavaScript snippet selenium.browserbot.getCurrentWindow(), and then run your JavaScript in there

function.name: setTimeout
function.param: a timeout in milliseconds, after which the action will return with an error
function.comment:
Specifies the amount of time that Selenium will wait for actions to complete.
Actions that require waiting include "open" and the "waitFor*" actions. The default timeout is 30 seconds.

function.name: waitForPageToLoad
function.param: a timeout in milliseconds, after which this command will return with an error
function.comment:
Waits for a new page to load.
You can use this command instead of the "AndWait" suffixes, "clickAndWait", "selectAndWait", "typeAndWait" etc. (which are only available in the JS API).
Selenium constantly keeps track of new pages loading, and sets a "newPageLoaded" flag when it first notices a page load. Running any other Selenium command after turns the flag to false. Hence, if you want to wait for a page to load, you must wait immediately after a Selenium command that caused a page-load.

function.name: getCookie
function.return: all cookies of the current page under test
function.comment: Return all cookies of the current page under test.

function.name: createCookie
function.param: name and value of the cookie in a format "name=value"

options for the cookie. Currently supported options include 'path' and 'max_age'. the optionsString's format is "path=/path/, max_age=60". The order of options are irrelevant, the unit of the value of 'max_age' is second.
function.comment: Create a new cookie whose path and domain are same with those of current page under test, unless you specified a path for this cookie explicitly.

function.name: deleteCookie
function.param: the name of the cookie to be deleted
the path property of the cookie to be deleted
function.comment: Delete a named cookie with specified path.

function.name: pause
function.param: the amount of time to sleep (in milliseconds)
function.comment: Wait for the specified amount of time (in milliseconds)

function.name: break
function.comment: Halt the currently running test, and wait for the user to press the Continue button. This command is useful for debugging, but be careful when using it, because it will force automated tests to hang until a user intervenes manually.

function.name: store
function.param: the value to store
the name of a variable in which the result is to be stored.
function.comment: This command is a synonym for storeExpression.

function.name: echo
function.param: the message to print
function.comment: Prints the specified message into the third table cell in your Selenese tables. Useful for debugging.

function.name: assertSelected
function.param: an element locator identifying a drop-down menu
an option locator, typically just an option label (e.g. "John Smith")
function.comment:
Verifies that the selected option of a drop-down satisfies the optionSpecifier. Note that this command is deprecated; you should use assertSelectedLabel, assertSelectedValue, assertSelectedIndex, or assertSelectedId instead.
See the select command for more information about option locators.

function.name: assertFailureOnNext
function.param: The failure message we should expect. This command will fail if the wrong failure message appears.
function.comment: Tell Selenium to expect a failure on the next command execution.

function.name: assertErrorOnNext
function.param: The error message we should expect. This command will fail if the wrong error message appears.
function.comment: Tell Selenium to expect an error on the next command execution.
